body: Opus 4.6 must be used for all Cortex implementation builds. Sonnet is acceptable for websites and throwaway MVPs only.

Decisions use dual-write pattern: concept in Mind (behavioral, decays) plus record in Vault (permanent). Multi-party decisions also get a relation entry. Agent judges what to write at observation time.
Mind and Vault both organize by type subdirectories. UUIDv7 filenames provide chronological ordering. mind/{type}/{id}.md and vault/{type}/{id}.md.
Rejected observations go to queue/quarantine.jsonl with rejection reason. Applies to validation failures and security rejections only. Normal filtering (dupes, below threshold) is not quarantined.
Wayne requires Opus 4.6 for all Cortex implementation builds. Sonnet is acceptable only for websites, throwaway MVPs, and file grinding. Critical software deserves the best available model.
Wayne believes that investing hours in specs is wasted if an inferior model interprets them into code. The model quality must match the spec quality.
Shell echo interprets escape sequences like \n as literal newlines, breaking JSONL entries. Always use printf to write JSON to queue files.
Vault partitioning (agent-owned vs app-owned sections) explored and deferred. Principle is sound but premature with one agent and zero applications. Revisit when a second vault consumer appears.
Wayne requires all taxonomy type definitions to follow the standard format: definition, three parts, what-it-is-not, quick test, examples. No shortcuts or abbreviated definitions.
Pre-build and post-build checklists are mandatory for all builds across all projects. Implemented as OpenClaw skills that auto-load before and after implementation work.
Run a Codex comparison build using the same Cortex v0.3.1 specs. Compare output quality against the Opus build to evaluate Codex as a coding model.

Decisions worth recording are consequential, directional, and often involve multiple parties. Trivial choices (what to eat) never enter the system. The write gate for decisions is significance, not frequency.
Wayne Vaughan. Owner of Cortex, SigmaRead, and related projects. Telegram @waynevaughan. Work hours 9AM-3:30PM CT then back late. Prefers autonomous execution and first-principles thinking.
